Palmer Larson

Madison Area Technical College

Biography

I am a Web Software Development Student at Madison Area Technical College. I currently work as an IT Support Specialist at EatStreet Inc. and have a bachelor's degree in Criminology from the University of Wisconsin - Whitewater.

Previously, I worked as a Deputy Sheriff at the Dane County Sheriff’s office in Madison, WI. After following the route of Law Enforcement through college and into the professional field I decided to follow my true interests leaving Law Enforcement and into IT. Though, this may seem like a strange career transition the valuable skills I have learned througout my time in the academy and in the field are many. I have learned many interpersonal and self-discipline skills, and most important problem solving skills. So far, throughout my schooling and IT career these learned skills from my past career have proven themselves invaluable and will continue to do so.

My passion is software development. I am constantly learning and adapting to new things in the technology field and I am enjoying the process.

January 2020

I was accepted into the Web Software Development program at Madison Area Technical College.

June 2020

Successfully completed my first semester in the Web Software Development program, gaining new skills in Javascript, HTML, and CSS.

December 2021

I finished my 2nd semester in the Web Software Developer program gaining new skills in Java, PHP, and Web Design.

January 2021

Earned a Promotion to IT as my current company EatStreet. Decided to take a semester off with intentions to return in the fall to focus on my quality of work while training.

March 2021

Began CodeAcademy and Scrimba to continue learning while out of school. Both have been tremendously helpful.

July 2021

Committed to #100DaysOfCode! Look below for more info!

#100DaysOfCode

Tweets by PalmerLarson4

On July 5th, 2021 I committed to the 100 days of code challenge. This challenge is just as is sounds, you code at least an hour a day for 100 days and tweet your progress.

The reasoning behind this challenge is to develop a habit of coding.

I committed to 100DaysOfCode to really challenge myself and gain momentum in learning programming.
